abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Maharashtra Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation "Jalswarajya" Project for
            India were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was low, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the project
            clearly demonstrated that investing in participatory
            processes to identify, articulate, and satisfy the demand
            for Water Supply and Sanitation (WSS) services at the level
            of the Gram Panchayats (GPs) might start slow, as it
            requires time to develop local capacity and decentralize
            delivery, but that the process pays off over time. In fact,
            the project registered a slow disbursement curve during the
            first two years of implementation and a very fast
            acceleration over the last three years, once capacities and
            local systems for service delivery were in place. Initial
            capacity building is an important activity to prioritize
            before the formation of local committees. Despite the fact
            that fully sustainable operation and maintenance of the
            assets delivered by the project has not yet been achieved
            across all the target GPs, the project created a basis for
            future sustainability by introducing the culture of paying
            for a service. A key lesson emerging from project
            implementation is that communities can be more effectively
            mobilized in smaller villages with more cohesive social
            backgrounds. Adaptation of fiduciary requirements to the
            demand-driven approach and large-scale intervention approach.
